captions.text: Kirk to engineering. Get us outta here, Scotty.
I'm giving her all she's got, captain.
Well that's not good enough.
If we eject the cores and detonate, the blast might be enough to push us away.
Do it! Do it! Do it!
Well that didn't work at all.
We are still caught in the gravitational pull.
What are we going to do, Captain?
We've gotta make this ship as light as possible. It's our only chance.
But we're in space.
Weight has nothing to do with----
Scotty I want you to jettison every crew member wearing a red shirt and any spare parts you've got.
But, I'm wearing a red shirt, Captain!
Just do it.
Aye, aye sir.
Still no effect, sir.
Grrr
I thought for sure that was gonna work.
I don't wanna die!!
Your orders are proving to be most illogical, Captain.
I know. Hold on, hold on. I'm thinking.
Okay, I've got an idea. Computer, I want you to shut down all the lens flare generators.
Lens flare generators deactivated.
Fascinating.
Ahh, that's better.
I was unaware that we had that.
It's nice, right?
I mean who designs a starship where lights shine right in your eyes from virtually every angle?
Captain, please!
Ok, so basically we're out of options.
We have no warp core.
We have no red shirts, we have no rescue.
Bones, any ideas?
Jim, if you make me say I'm a doctor not a magician I'm gonna come up there and punch you in the--
Right, he's got no ideas.
There is one thing left we can do...
Turn this ship around.

Captain, even if we survive it is
unpredictable when or where the ship will emerge on the other side.

Well, we don't have much of a choice now
do we, Spock?

Plus we're explorers right? We'll figure
something out. That's what we do.
Mr. Sulu, take us through the black hole.
Yes, sir.
Space... the final frontier.

These are the voyages of the Starship
Enterprise.

It's continuing mission: to explore
strange new worlds.
to seek out new life and new civilizations
to boldly go where no man has gone be---
(Boom!!)
Oh.. we are going to get so much crap for that.
Ohhh Ohhhhhhh..

title: Star Trek: How It Should Have Ended

comments.text:
Spock is wrong. Mass is still relevant here since, according to Newton's 
second law, ma=sum of F. At equal propelling force F, the lighter object 
will accelerate faster than the heavier one. Now it is true that the 
gravitational pull of the black hole will be the same regardless of mass, 
since ma=mg, where g is the gravitational field of the black hole.﻿

required to escape a gravitational force is proportional to mass (F=mA), 
reducing the ship's mass would actually help.  (just sayin')

dry mass of the Enterprise....﻿

comments.author: Morpheus LP

comments.text:
you know, the ending was actually scientifically innacurate. scotty says 
they're at warp, meaning capable of going faster than the speed of light. 
meanwhile, the ship still cant break the black holes gravity.

you see, the surface of black holes are actually an illusion called the 
event horizon. basically, light beyond that point cant escape the gravity 
to reach our eyes. so, the event horizon isnt a physical thing, just a 
veil. HOWEVER, if your ship is capable of reaching speeds of warp 10 (as 
in, 10 times the speed of light), then your ship is actually capable of not 
only escaping a black hole's gravity, but is actually capable of doing it 
from INSIDE the event horizon. pretty cool, eh?

but what this means is that it shouldve been a piece of cake for the 
enterprise to escape in that last scene, being at warp, and being OUTSIDE 
the event horizon. even if it were inside the event horizon, it wouldve 
escaped.

ive noticed many scientific inaccuracies in these 2 most recent movies. 
however, it's pretty clear the writers know their science, and simply leave 
those inaccuracies in there for the sake of cool action sequences, fake 
smart talk mumbo jumbo, and good story telling... i mean, escaping on an 
explosion? yeah, that was pretty cool. so i guess they cant really be 
blamed for it.

... oh, and with the nature of warp drives, the glass in the view screen 
shouldnt have cracked or been affected at all.﻿

comments.author: Joe Beauchamp

comments.text:
+Joe Beauchamp I knew some twit like you would make a comment like that.

as ive said... REPEATEDLY... in past comments, the "warp drive" in star 
trek was actually based on a real world idea known as an Alcubierre drive. 
the physics behind the Alcubierre drive were predicted BEFORE star trek 
even became a show.

PS, Alcubierre is the name of the PHYSICIST who came up with the idea... so 
yeah, it is a real world idea dreamed up by a real world scientist. it is 
FEASIBLE in the real world, and because of the way it works, has very 
predictable physics behind it.

no, a warp drive has never been built, and probably wont be for some 
time... but that doesn't matter in the slightest. because of HOW a warp 
drive works, it's fairly easy to predict how a real world warp drive would 
react in a situation like this. so yeah, ignoring MOVIE PHYSICS, a real 
warp drive would respond exactly as I said it would. this is what I mean 
when I say things like real world warp drive mechanics.

key word "mechanics" I never actually said "a real world warp drive", just 
the physics behind how a real warp drive would work.

now fuck off, unless you plan on skimming through the rest of my comments 
to find something else innocuous to nit pick and troll about.

comments.text:
+Marianne Ibbotson HEY, i actually never knew that. why have i always heard 
it's times the speed of light?

well, the magnitude system you described makes MUCH more sense that the 
other system. it's actually scientifically accurate. at 10 times the speed 
of light, it'd still take you about 5 months just to get to alpha centuri. 
with the magnitude system, it actually explains WHY it takes all of 5 
minutes to go between systems. it also explains why warp 10 is basically 
the top speed.

and all the more argument for my point too. if your ship can go warp 10 
with the magnitude system (as you described, almost instantaneous 
transportation), the ship can actually go fast enough to escape from damn 
near on top of the singularity in a black hole.
comments.author: justme man

comments.text:
Actually just to go all full hopeless nerd mode on you, warp 10 does not 
mean 10 times the speed of light. In Star Trek set before TNG, a warp 
factor's speed in multiples of c (the speed of light) is that warp factor 
cubed, i.e. to the power of 3, so warp 10 is 1000 times the speed of light 
(10x10x10). In TNG and later, warp factors 1-9 are the factor to the power 
of 3.333... and factors above 9 are calculated to an ever higher power with 
warp 10 being infinite speed, and (generally) impossible to reach. Now that 
you know this invaluable information, you can avoid terrible social faux 
pas at Star Trek conventions!
comments.author: Marianne Ibbotson

comments.text:
+SUMOTACHI the wiki i put up said nothing ABOUT black holes, so you clearly 
never read it.

this one, on the other hand, is about black holes:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole

read the part about the singularity. as i said, it is the only part of the 
black hole that is warped to an infinite degree.

there are other ways in which you're wrong. a ship powered by a warp drive 
isnt the only thing that can escape a black hole. ever hear of hawkings 
radiation? if, mathematically speaking, all straight lines lead into the 
singularity inside the event horizon, then hawking radiation would not work:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawking_radiation

why dont YOU start posting some evidence to how im wrong. otherwise, this 
is just a pissing contest between 2 people who dont have perfect 
understandings of science (though some understandings are more perfect than 
others).
comments.author: justme man

comments.text:
I guess not! Cause like I said your focusing on the drive and not the and 
not how a black hole works. Which you're still saying wrong despite that 
being on the wiki also.
comments.author: SUMOTACHI

comments.text:
+SUMOTACHI will you please read the god damned wiki? the warp drive is not 
sci fi, the physics behind it are based in reality. you keep saying shit 
like "warp tunnels and sub space" and it's clear you havent the slightest 
clue what the points im trying to make are.

yes, a black hole warps space time, but you keep acting like everything 
inside the event horizon is automatically warped to an infinite degree... 
this is NOT the case. the only spot in space time inside a black hole where 
this is the case is the singularity. if the ship is sitting right on top of 
the singularity, then yes, not even a warp drive will save the ship. but if 
the ship is between the singularity and the event horizon, space time is 
still in a fairly normal state, and the ship can escape.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcubierre_drive

seriously, READ IT. dont comment again unless your first paragraph tells me 
from your perspective exactly how a warp drive works, because i cant really 
tell if you're even on the same page here.
comments.author: justme man

comments.text:
Because you're focus on the drive and not the physic of nothing can escape 
a black hole. There is nothing that says an object must travel faster than 
light to escape a black hole only that  light can't escape it.

Second I think you'reconfusion is what the a black hole's interior is 
comprised of v. what the drive is doing v. what we see in start trek.

If 'We're talking about warp tunnels and sub-space then not relay going to 
work because that Si-fi shows perspective

I talking about normal space. My familiarity "real world theory" is that it 
warps space in front and back and slingshots you forward. Only the ship 
sits in a bubble unaffected by time/inertia to a point.  

So your pinch point is it does not matter if your drive warps space, 
because space is already warped. Thus like I said "all" points with a black 
holes event horizon lead into the black hole. I would love to see the math 
that goes into warping black hole space so you can escape it when time and 
space already being affected in real time.

Oh and calm your tits I am having fun!
comments.author: SUMOTACHI

comments.text:
+SUMOTACHI what? no, im not agreeing with you, for god's sakes, read the 
damned wiki! black holes aren't used to make warp drives, exactly as I said.

a black hole drive is COMPLETELY different from a warp drive.

yes, warp drives warp space, it's in their name. and yes, that's the point 
that im making, a warp drive can counter the effects of a black hole, which 
is why a ship powered by one can escape from inside the event horizon.

and no, the warp drive doesn't need to counter the effects all the way 
across the black hole, it would never have the power to do so. ALL it needs 
to do is counter the effects in the vicinity of the ship (which is, by 
design, what it already does).

it's all about relatives, so the warp drive doesn't need to COUNTER the 
black hole's pull to escape, all it needs to do is create a warp bubble 
(meaning the gravity can no longer affect the ship in the first place 
anyway since the warp bubble essentially cuts it off from the black hole's 
influence), and expand space time behind it, and compress space time in 
front of it. this propels the spacecraft.

so, whatever the warp drive has to do, it will simply add on to the 
conditions already around the bubble. if space time is already compressed 
in front of the ship, it will simply compress it further. if space time is 
already compressed behind the ship, it will still expand it. maybe not to 
the same degree as it would outside the event horizon, but then, it doesn't 
have to, ANY expansion or compression in these conditions will still propel 
the ship.

you keep thinking of this like a ship fighting a current. if the current is 
strong enough, no amount of power will save the ship. but that's not how 
warp drives work, they are a reactionless drive. they practically CREATE a 
wave in the water upon which the ship can ride, no matter what the water 
underneath is doing.

this is actually a perfect analogy for a warp drive, since compressing 
space time in front of a ship and expanding it behind it pretty much does 
create a wave in space time, a wave upon which a ship can ride, no matter 
what the space time beneath it is doing.

this is the loop hole that warp drives use to go faster than the speed of 
light in the first place. although ships cannot go faster than the speed of 
light, they can ride a warp bubble (a wave in space time), technically be 
standing still, but use the wave to ride to faster than light speeds.

again, read the wiki, it explains in greater detail. if you read it, you'll 
see why a warp drive can get a ship out of a black hole.

I don't understand why this is such a difficult concept for people anyway. 
the warp drive can go faster than the speed of light, so just by that fact 
alone, a ship powered by one can escape the event horizon (which is an 
imaginary barrier dictated only by the fact that it is the point at which 
light cannot escape a black hole)
comments.author: justme man

comments.text:
Then you're agreeing whit me, that what said. It does not matter if the 
drive is engaged you in warped space already space which has no return 
point that can be calculated.

So what your trying to say is a warp drive which is not deigned around a 
black hole, can warp space around an entire black hole area of influence to 
make a straight line out of it.
comments.author: SUMOTACHI

comments.text:
+SUMOTACHI if you'd read the wiki i showed you, you'd see the warp drive im 
talking about has absolutely nothing to do with worm holes or mini black 
holes. it's a well known nerd fact that the warp drive in star trek is 
BASED ON the alcubierre drive. the alcubierre drive, in this case, would 
put the ship under conditions independent of whatever's going on outside 
the warp bubble... so no, time dilation and other such phenomena would not 
affect the ship.

black hole drives are a reaction based drive, but are not featured anywhere 
in the star trek universe (that i know of). worm hole drives, although more 
logical than an alcubierre drive (in that they would require very similar 
technology, but worm holes are faster), are also not featured anywhere in 
the series (that i know of). and the antimatter drive has nothing to do 
with the warp drive.

it is also a well known nerd fact that the enterprise has 2 forms of 
propulsion, one being the FTL warp drive, and the other being the impulse 
drive

this "impulse" drive is actually just your ordinary antimatter engine 
(which is what i think you're referring to) HAD the enterprise been using 
it, then yes, it would not have escaped, even outside the event horizon.

but it was using the warp drive, not the impulse drive. warp drives require 
a lot of energy, so while i could see them being POWERED by antimatter 
powered generators, it is not the antimatter itself propelling the ship. 
imagine it like the hybrid diesel electric systems used on ships today (the 
antimatter being the diesel, the electric being the warp drive).
comments.author: justme man

comments.text:
+justme man
We are talking mathematical points. And yes past the "event horizon" all 
points lead into the black hole, that being the space comprised of it. Its 
on the wiki so it should be else where to cover the fact . 

(Nerd talk): Secondly the type of Warp drive Star Trek has is the 
Anti-matter type and not the micro black hole or worm hole type. the latter 
which comprised instantaneous travel. thus time will have to past.  You 
want to take 0-infinity years to do that calculation. But hey its Si-fi so 
just pick how much time you want to take like they did.
comments.author: SUMOTACHI

comments.text:
+Brian Mcbrian yeah, you're right about the space battles being a little 
retarded. that's true of all cinematic sci fi.

however, i do think there's some scientific validity to star trek. even 
more so then many other sci fis (especially star wars). the warp drive is 
essentially a real world theoretical device called an Alcubierre drive:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcubierre_drive

this is based in science. all that's lacking is the technology required to 
build one, though, with negative kelvin bose einstein condensates, that may 
change in the next century or two.

additionally, i've seen them make other unusual scientific references. it 
seems they know their stuff, but intentionally get stuff wrong. for 
instance, the cold fusion bomb in the sequel is total bullshit. there's no 
device known capable of freezing a volcano

and the words "cold fusion" is relative. all it means is fusion occurs at a 
temperature far lower than the several million degrees it would normally 
take.

HOWEVER, the tiny ring device that was later dropped in a glass of water to 
produce an explosion in the lab... THIS phenomenon looks exactly like cold 
fusion. the ring is a catalyst for the hydrogen in the water to fuse. no 
such material exists, but there are some that get close. palladium was 
famously used in the Fleichmann and Pons cold fusion device. though it 
needed to be electrified, and the reaction occured far slower, the 
palladium does act as a catalyst for cold fusion (in theory. the debate on 
the fleichmann and pons device is a fierce one).

so, it's clear they get what cold fusion is, yet intentionally get it 
wrong. they do this repeatedly throughout the new movies, and i really cant 
understand why.

star wars, on the other hand, requires much bigger leaps of the imagination 
to make that logic work.

but if you want a show that actually cares about scientific accuracy, i'd 
suggest star gate SG1. it's pretty cool what they do with physics in some 
of those episodes.
comments.author: justme man

comments.author: TheCollegeConundrum

comments.text:
+Vikas Gupta I doubt its possible as well, however, if we have been able to 
establish "warp speed" which is ftl travel, it would be consistent with 
this universe's technological level.  And yes, it is a theory, but 
generally black holes are considered single sided, thats just the 
conventions.  However, it is true that they potentially wouldnt have been 
able to distinguish the difference between the two without some sort of 
advanced detector [perhaps wormholes emit a different radiation, who 
knows].  So my entire point boils down to, although they maybe cannot tell 
if it is a wormhole or not, using the convention "black hole" indicates a 
single side.
comments.author: TheCollegeConundrum

comments.text:
+TheCollegeConundrum well i completely agree with you too, but my point 
again was that we don't actually know , even though the most probable 
theory says so. And  I also believe as long as i can't prove a theory, i 
can't talk in certainty even though how sure i am and so it is just a 
theory and if anybody want he can reject my theory, so i just don't like 
the idea of ppl saying anything like it is a fact even without  making sure 
how much evidence is there to support it. and about the scapegoat thing , i 
really don't  think it will be possible in our lifetime,so just guesses and 
mathematical theories for us.
comments.author: Vikas Gupta

comments.text:
+Vikas Gupta Well the prevailing theory is that it folds into a fourth 
spacial dimension [assuming m theory is correct and there are 12] , and if 
you say black hole, the general idea is that it is single sided [It would 
be like playing Russian roulette if you were just guessing which one is a 
black hole and which one is a wormhole].  And I completely agree with you 
on the ripped apart thing [after all, Ive done problem set after problem 
set proving that what you say is correct], however, if they are even 
thinking about going into a black hole/wormhole, you would have to be 
sufficiently advanced in technology to produce some "exotic matter" [a 
scapegoat of sorts] to cause anti-grav effects.  If you were going into a 
wormhole, that type of exotic matter would have to exist to widen the hole.
comments.author: TheCollegeConundrum

comments.text:
+Grinch 75R You know it because we can model the time dilation and 
gravitational gradient seen in a black hole.  We know that the difference 
in force between points is so great that it causes points to be ripped 
apart.  Einstein derived the theory. Its called general relativity. And you 
can tell things though mathematical proofs and watching stars being torn 
apart by black holes. You dont have to experience it to know it to be true. 
 For example, if I were to shoot you into the middle of the sun, I know you 
would burn up instantaneously. Would you like to test my theory?
comments.author: TheCollegeConundrum

comments.text:
+Vikas Gupta finally someone with brains people keep saying you'll die. How 
do they know did you experience it you r the one of the few.
